content: The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" defines terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area, Program, and Secretary for the establishment of a fisheries restoration and irrigation mitigation program. The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" defines terms for the establishment of a fisheries restoration and irrigation mitigation program. SEC. 3 establishes the program. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior with the goals of reducing fish mortality due to water withdrawal for irrigation and preventing fish from entering water supply systems. The Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries. Under the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, the Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries from water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area, including fish screens and passage devices. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Projects eligible under the Program include fish screens, fish passage devices, and related features agreed upon by stakeholders. The Secretary will prioritize projects with a total cost of less than $5,000,000. Participation in the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is voluntary for non-Federal entities. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they choose to participate. Federal expenditures for projects on U.S. owned land will not be reimbursed. Projects under the Program will be evaluated and prioritized based on a total cost of less than $5,000,000. Evaluation and prioritization of projects for development under the Program will be based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements will also be considered. Projects under the Program must meet Secretary and State requirements, and have approval from all relevant entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and utilize available data to determine project eligibility. Cost sharing is also addressed. The non-Federal share of project costs on non-Federal land is 35%. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land and resources for the project, which will be credited towards the project's value. The non-Federal participants in a project on non-Federal land must provide land and resources, which will be credited towards the project's value. They are responsible for all costs associated with operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing the project. Non-Federal participants in projects on non-Federal land must cover all costs for project operation, maintenance, repair, rehabilitation, and replacement. The Federal Government is responsible for these costs on projects carried out on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. SEC. 9. REPORT. Projects funded under this Act are ineligible for receiving Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress after the third fiscal year, detailing completed projects, projects to be completed in the future, and any recommended changes to the Program based on the projects carried out under this Act. Authorization of appropriations for projects funded under this Act. Authorization of appropriations for projects funded under this Act is set at $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005, with limitations on the use of funds in a single state and administrative expenses capped at 6 percent. The Act authorizes $25,000,000 for projects annually from 2001 to 2005, with a 6 percent cap on administrative expenses. States can waive funding limitations if unable to utilize the full amount allocated.
